abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Emergency Infrastructure
            Rehabilitation and Living Conditions Improvement Project of
            Congo were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            unsatisfactory, the risk to development outcome was high,
            the Bank performance was moderately unsatisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was moderately unsatisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: 1) A multi-faceted approach to
            mitigating capacity constraints is necessary in a
            post-conflict environment; 2) Cost overruns are common
            features of emergency operations dealing with infrastructure
            activities and higher levels of unallocated resources are
            needed to address the higher level of uncertainty; 3)
            Expectations in achieving results in emergency operations
            should remain low, particularly in the absence of
            information on indicators and baselines; 4) Balancing long
            term sustainability and short term impacts is a difficult
            exercise and normal Bank operations should immediately
            follow the completion of emergency operations to address
            long term sustainability; and 5) Project performance is at
            risk when project restructuring is not carried out timely.
